Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Biotic Surveys of Central Saharan Oases
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative research project aims to survey comprehensively the fauna of isolated desert oases in Libya and Egypt. Surveys will focus on vertebrate and parasite diversity, with focal research on amphibians, fishes, reptiles, mollusks, and schistosome and hematozoan parasites. Using new GIS data and geo-referenced historical records, the geographical relationship between the Mediterranean and sub-Saharan faunas will be mapped. With a new collection of specimens that includes tissue samples, long-standing biogeographic hypotheses will be tested via molecular phylogenetic methods. By revisiting historical localities, important new data will be provided on changes in faunal composition driven by recent aridification. Analyses of new genetic, morphological, and ecological data will also provide a window into the evolutionary dynamics of refugial populations, including adaptation to extreme environments. Specimens, tissues, and data will be deposited in publicly accessible U.S. museum collections and databases and will serve as an important resource for future work on North African biodiversity. New distributional data on parasites, including schistosome worms, and on venomous snakes will have a direct effect on managing human health. These isolated oases are threatened by climate change, including a water table that is diminishing because of regional changes in water utilization; the investigators' surveys will draw attention to the fragility of these irreplaceable ecosystems. Through collaboration with foreign and U.S. museums, important historical specimen collections from Libya and Egypt will be updated and curated. This project includes diverse specialties and institutions, and integrates North African researchers and students in fieldwork and the resulting research. Undergraduate and graduate students will be included in both field surveys and subsequent research. This project will provide the resources for conducting taxonomic revisions, pursuing broad-scale phylogeographic studies, and applying molecular genetic tools to long-standing problems in African biogeography. This project is co-funded by the National Science Foundation's Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied evolutionary patterns of amphibians and reptiles throughout Africa but concentrated on areas that were particularly poorly known (Angola and Libya) as well as areas of especially high diversity (Cameroon and Namibia). Within these areas we collected, identified and described new species of amphibians and reptiles; assembled, verified, and georeferenced existing museum and literature records; and combined these with our newly collected data.

We used molecular phylogenetic and phylogeographic methods to determine evolutionary patterns of relationship among a diversity of diverse groups of African frogs. We determined that while the Afrobatrachia (a lineage representing more than half of all African frogs) originated in the Cretaceous, a number of the most diverse genera originated much later in the Miocene. We studied the evolution of reproductive diversity in this lineage and found associations between particular types of adult ecology and sites of egg-laying. We found that arboreal species exhibit a shift toward using breeding sites associated with slow-moving water. Using several examples of widespread African frogs, our work reveals that both rivers and forest refuges play a role in explaining patterns of genetic and phylogenetic diversity.

In addition to phylogenetic studies, research both in the field and with museum collections generated other significant results. Our field-based research resulted in novel findings on the biology of species encountered. This includes that certain colorful treefrogs do not have alkaloids in the skin, and that sympatric species of caecilian may partition diet by the hardness of their invertebrate prey with one species frequently consuming an important agricultural pest (mole crickets). Our research in Libya, Namibia and Angola resulted in the comprehensive mapping of all locality records (from museum collections and the literature) for these countries, providing the first realistic estimate of herpetofaunal diversity in the last of these, and demonstrating its critical significance as an area of faunal turnover from arid southwestern Africa to humid central Africa. This has revealed distributional patterns that are informative with respect to both evolutionary and ecological patterns at scales ranging from the populational to the familial, and has identified areas that are in need of further biodiversity exploration. The data have additional practical applications such as the mapping of the distribution of dangerously venomous snakes. Collectively, this project has contributed to the natural history and biotic inventory of Africa, which remains one the most poorly documented regions of the world.

This research has strengthened U.S. scientific infrastructure by providing technical training in laboratory and field techniques to three Masters students, two PhD students, and two postdoctoral scholars, by contributing several thousand museum and DNA tissue samples to publically accessible collections, and by disseminating the findings of our research in 13 published peer-reviewed journal articles so far (with more in review or in preparation), and more than 20 conference presentations. We trained one doctoral student from Cameroon, a postdoctoral scholar from Portugal, and several colleagues from other countries which strengthened or initiated new international collaborations. We also established a working collaboration with Angolan colleagues, including the training of local students in field and museum techniques, that is facilitating future research in that country. This represents not only the first American herpetological research program in Angola, but the first substantial herpetological research of any kind since the county’s independence in 1975.
